question.title: How to go from time zone abbreviation, such as PST, to canonical expansion for the locale
question.body:
Is there a method in the Java standard library, or in some package such as JodaTime, which can expand a time zone abbreviation such as PST to the full name of that time zone appropriate for the locale? For example, PST can be either Asia/Manila, America/Los_Angeles, America/Vancouver, or many others depending on whether the user is in the Philippines, US, Canada, etc. I know there's getAvailableIDs in either JDK or JodaTime, but both provide an exhaustive list and don't give any guidance on which to pick in the event the user just says PST. Ideally there would be something that uses the Locale to pick the closest or most relevant time zone.

Edit: I need to check further, but the comment below from Anonymous was the answer I was looking for. The following code behaves as I would like:

    ZoneId zone = ZoneId.from(DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("z", Locale.US).parse("MST"));
    System.out.println(zone.getId());

    zone = ZoneId.from(DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("z", Locale.CANADA).parse("MST"));
    System.out.println(zone.getId());

result:

America/Denver
America/Edmonton

It doesn't work perfectly, such as Locale.CHINA and CST still gives America/Chicago instead of a time zone in China, but this is a lot closer than having to guess when we get an ambiguous time zone as input.
